etymologies: Middle English (denoting an emir or Saracen commander): from Old French amiral, admirail, via medieval Latin from Arabic 'amīr ‘commander’ (from 'amara ‘to command’). The ending -al was from Arabic -al- ‘of the’, used in titles (e.g. 'amīr-al-'umarā ‘ruler of rulers’), later assimilated to the familiar Latinate suffix -al

definitions: a commander of a fleet or naval squadron, or a naval officer of very high rank.
a commissioned officer of very high rank in the US Navy or Coast Guard, ranking above a vice admiral.

crossReferenceMarkers: short for vice admiral or rear admiral

definitions: a butterfly that has dark wings with bold colorful markings.

notes.text: Several species in the subfamilies Limenitidinae and Nymphalinae, family Nymphalidae. See red admiral, white admiral
